title: Workplace Finger Fracture in an Assembly Line Worker: A Case Study
clinical_history: Mr. Ravi Sharma, a 43-year-old right-handed factory assembly line worker, presents with acute pain and swelling of his left ring finger. The injury occurred 3 days ago when his finger was caught between two conveyor components at his workplace. He reports immediate sharp pain, significant swelling, and difficulty moving the affected digit. Since the incident, Mr. Sharma notes persistent tenderness and trouble gripping objects with his left hand, which is now interfering with both work tasks and daily activities such as buttoning his shirt. There is mild bruising along the dorsal aspect of the proximal phalanx, and he reports that touching or bumping the finger exacerbates the pain. No other injuries or systemic symptoms are reported.

nprs.affected_area: left ring finger proximal phalanx (fracture site)
surrounding soft tissue swelling and adjacent digits

aggrevating_factors: Gripping, attempting to make a fist, typing, accidental pressure on the finger, and cold exposure
picture: Image depicting swelling, bruising, and partial malalignment of the left ring finger proximal phalanx
easing_factors: Keeping the finger elevated, applying ice intermittently, resting the hand, and using over-the-counter pain medication
past_history: No previous fractures or major hand injuries. Occasional mild joint pain from repetitive use, but nothing requiring medical attention.
medical_history: Non-contributory. No known comorbidities such as diabetes or osteoporosis. Up-to-date on tetanus immunization.
medications: Paracetamol 500 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain
personal_history: Non-smoker, social alcohol use, lives with wife and two school-aged children. He is the primary earner for the household and is anxious about time off work due to financial concerns.
imaging: AP and lateral radiographs of the left hand confirm a non-displaced transverse fracture of the proximal phalanx of the left ring finger.
